patient_information: A 32-year-old man from Malawi. His past medical history is unremarkable except for an episode of a blistering and painful skin lesion 3 years previously, affecting the right side of his abdomen, which healed spontaneously and was likely herpes zoster. The patient was subsequently found to be HIV positive.
chief_complaint: A history of right upper abdominal pain and a feeling of faintness, particularly on standing and walking.
history_of_present_illness: The patient was well until one month prior to admission, when he developed a feeling of fullness in his upper abdomen. In the week before admission, he experienced pain in the right upper abdomen, which was more apparent when sleeping on his right side. He recently began to feel breathless on lying down and faint, especially upon standing up.
exposure_and_epidemiology: The patient is from Malawi, a region where tuberculosis is highly endemic. The history of a skin lesion suggestive of herpes zoster is a strong pointer to underlying HIV infection, which is common in tuberculosis patients in central and southern Africa.
vitals: On presentation, his pulse was regular at 130 bpm with a pronounced pulsus paradoxus of 15 mmHg. Blood pressure in the supine position was 90/60 mm Hg. Following pericardiocentesis, his blood pressure increased to 120/80 mmHg almost immediately.
physical_exam: The patient was thin and slightly breathless in a supine position. His jugular venous pulse appeared elevated. The apex beat was impalpable, and heart sounds were quiet but audible. Auscultation of the chest was normal. Examination revealed an enlarged, tender palpable liver measured at 8 cm below the right costal junction, along with mild peripheral oedema of the legs and sacral area.
labs_and_diagnostics: Laboratory results showed a haemoglobin of 10.5 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 9.8 G/L. A chest radiograph demonstrated an enlarged, globular heart with clear lung fields. An HIV test was positive. Therapeutic pericardial aspiration yielded 500 mL of bloodstained pericardial fluid. An ultrasound of the heart was recommended to confirm pericardial fluid and an electrocardiogram to show low-voltage QRS complexes.
differential_diagnosis: The clinical findings of tachycardia, pulsus paradoxus, hypotension, impalpable apex beat, raised jugular venous pressure, and quiet heart sounds pointed to a diagnosis of pericardial tamponade from a large pericardial effusion. In Africa, causes include tuberculosis, other bacterial infections, malignancy, and HIV-related Kaposi's sarcoma. Given the patient's prior herpes zoster suggesting HIV and the high endemicity, the most likely diagnosis was considered to be HIV-associated tuberculosis.
management_and_clinical_course: The patient underwent therapeutic pericardial aspiration, removing 500 mL of fluid, which resulted in immediate blood pressure improvement. He was started on standard first-line antituberculous therapy (rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, ethambutol for 2 months, followed by rifampicin and isoniazid for 4 months) and prednisolone at 60 mg daily, tapered over ten weeks. Antiretroviral therapy was initiated 4 weeks after starting tuberculosis treatment. The patient made a full and uneventful recovery.
final_diagnosis: The final diagnosis was pericardial tamponade secondary to tuberculous pericarditis in the context of newly diagnosed HIV infection. This was supported by the clinical signs of tamponade, an enlarged globular heart on chest X-ray, the aspiration of 500mL of bloodstained pericardial fluid, and the patient's positive HIV status. The diagnosis of tuberculosis as the cause was presumptive but highly likely given the epidemiology in Malawi and the patient's dramatic and full recovery on antituberculous therapy.
